title: 114_s1600
content: The Act titled "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. These civil remedies are exclusive and subject to the same rights and limitations as individuals under the Privacy Act. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals under the Privacy Act when pursuing civil remedies. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of other officials, may designate a foreign country or organization as a "covered country" if they have an agreement with the US that provides privacy protections for shared information related to criminal offenses. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if they share information with the US for preventing criminal offenses and have privacy protections. The designation can be revoked if the country does not comply with the agreement. The Attorney General determines non-compliance of a designated "covered country" with the agreement, revokes designation if requirements are not met, or if the country obstructs information transfer to the US. The Attorney General designates federal agencies or components for enforcement, requiring concurrence from relevant agency heads. The Attorney General may designate a federal agency as a "designated Federal agency or component" if information exchanged with a covered country aligns with an agreement or if it serves law enforcement interests. Determinations made by the Attorney General are published in the Federal Register and are not subject to review. The Attorney General's determinations under subsections (d) and (e) are published and not subject to review. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over claims under this section. Definitions in the Act include terms like "agency," "covered country," "covered person," and "covered record." The section discusses the transfer of covered records to designated Federal agencies for criminal investigation purposes. It defines terms like "individual" and "designated Federal agency or component." It also clarifies that privileges are preserved, and classified information disclosure is not required. The Act preserves privileges and does not require disclosure of classified information. The district court will review agency submissions in camera and ex parte. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
